repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_regular_data.body: It looks like the timing of this callback is not running correctly. best run after buffer accepts textedit.   but there have https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/22598 can work in this situation i think ?

hm... it should be getting called after the [`textDocument/formatting` handler](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/22d9338afceae5f8ef3845f152dea07a19d512d1/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/handlers.lua#L321) I think?

Edit: do you mean it's being run too late or too soon?
after handler . but still think #22598 can handle this.

Well, #22598 can wrap the `textDocument/formatting` handler, I guess you could do something like

```
vim.lsp.handlers['textDocument/formatting'] = vim.on_fun(vim.lsp.handlers, 'textDocument/formatting', function(fn, args)
  local rv = fn(unpack(args))
  vim.cmd.update()
  return rv
end)
```

The problem with this approach is that it is an all-or-nothing approach, at that point all the `format` calls would end up `updating` too, etc

What I mean is that it is best to run after the buffer accepts textedit, after the buffer is formatted. But also add the client counter to run the callback after the last textedit of the client that had a textedit result returned.

> why not just use
> 
> ```lua
> vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd("BufWritePost", {
> 	group = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup("FormatAutogroup", {}),
> 	callback = function()
>                 vim.lsp.buf.format()
>                 vim.cmd.update()
> 	end,
> })
> ```

Because that is blocking

> What I mean is that it is best to run after the buffer accepts textedit, after the buffer is formatted. But also add the client counter to run the callback after the last textedit of the client that had a textedit result returned.

hm... could you point me to some docs maybe explaining what you mean? I'm not that familiar with vim/neovim internals ^^;;

the buffer format by `util.apply_text_edits` . it receive the textedit and format buffer. I think you can do it on your local like

```lua
local original = vim.lsp.util.apply_text_edits

local total = #vim.lsp.get_clients( { bufnr = 0 ,method = vim.lsp.protocol.Method.textDocument_formatting })

 vim.lsp.util.apply_text_edits = function(text_edits, bufnr, offset_encoding)
        total = total - 1
        original(text_edits, bufnr, offset_encoding)
         if total == 0 then
                  do callback .
         end
end
```

maybe currently no need add a callback. most things need handle in #22598

hm... that would still end up overriding default handlers (which could be surprising to end users if it's done inside a plugin for example), it requires also internal knowledge of the function (`vim.lsp.util.apply_text_edits`)... I think this PR is slightly different in its approach

btw, I took my cues for this PR from https://github.com/lukas-reineke/lsp-format.nvim/blob/ca0df5c8544e51517209ea7b86ecc522c98d4f0a/lua/lsp-format/init.lua#L190, which is doing basically what I am doing here, only he is using the lsp client directly, I'm guessing because there would be no other way to hook into the callback

This would kinda conflict with the plan/idea outlined in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/22598#issuecomment-1463367606

Although lsp.buf.format is already a bit an outlier because it is sync by default and has the async flag, I'd at least wait with this PR until we've a clearer picture for the remaining functions.
Having a somewhat consistent interface across the functions improves usability so I'd like to avoid increasing the disparity further.
Gotcha! Well, the `async` version of `format` is lacking in functionality as it is, so in the meantime you'd need the approach from `lsp-format`, but yeah, I'll follow that discussion in the meantime

title: feat(lsp): add callback argument to lsp.buf.format
